title: PLEASE RIOT, I need to negate a role.
body:
Please do this thing. If we choose "Fill" let us negate another one.


EDIT:
Apparently we dont need good team comp, we need to loose games faster. 
And here i was thinking gaining LP was more important then how fast you get in to a game. 

Maybe I am wrong and anyone can support.

If you are a primary mid and secondary support because you like to play mages in mid and support, you have to choose between learning a new secondary or becoming a support main.

I think I get what Snake is saying. 

If SenorTaco chooses support secondary, he'll be getting support a lot of the time. When he gets tired of getting support, he can switch secondaries! He's not bound to always picking support secondary. Senor implies that he can play top, jungle, and middle at least adequately, so he can just switch his secondary from support to some other role that isn't bottom or his primary.

While that does make an adequate degree of sense, the issue is that having a "fill, but" option would reduce queue times whereas snakes whole argument revolves around the fact that if you don't want support then don't do it, but fill should maintain an 80% chance of giving you support which increases queue times across the board.

Would it really decrease queue times though?

Let's think this through.

Firstly, let's say that there are people who are comfortable in one, two, or three roles, and never choose fill because they have a decent chance of getting a role they don't want. Most of these people probably would not pick the "fill but" option if it were implemented, because they will still have a chance to get a role that they don't want. Some may change over because the chance to get that role may be small and the queue times will be smaller. So, this group will slightly decrease queue times because of a small group of people switching to "fill but" secondary.

Then let's take the people who are comfortable in one, two, three, or four roles but still choose secondary fill anyways because they want low queue times and/or want to give other people low queue times and/or because they're indecisive in what role they want. The people who want to keep their queue times as low as possible will retain their fill secondary and queue times will not change. People that feel really uncomfortable or tired with one role will exclude that role, decreasing the amount of players wanting that role and increasing queue times. The indecisive ones will also probably exclude the role that they don't want to play. This group will lead to an increase in queue times.

Then, the people comfortable in four roles who do not pick fill because of that dreaded fifth role. They will, undoubtedly, switch over to the "fill but" option, decreasing queue times.

Then there's the primary fillers who are comfortable in all roles. Most of these will probably stay primary fill, but if some are getting particularly tired of one role, they may change to the "fill but" option. This will increase queue times.

Then there are the primary fills who aren't comfortable in all roles. Most will probably change to "fill but", except for the ones who want lower queue times. This will increase queue times.

I think that covers most people. 

Now, I think Snake On Bush was talking about that second group, the group that takes fill secondary because of lower queue times or the goodness of its members' hearts, despite not wanting to play one or more roles. They're going to switch over to this "fill but" option and increase queue times. Why they're doing this is what puzzles him: they're potentially taking roles they don't want by selecting fill, and are complaining about it, when said problem could be fixed by not selecting fill and instead selecting another secondary. Why must we pander to these people and increase queue times?

On the other hand, there's the third group, the one that will decrease queue times because it's not selecting fill because of one role. Does this third group outweigh the second group, resulting in decreased queue times? (The first, fourth, and fifth groups will probably have negligible effect on the queue times if this change is implemented.)

That'd be something to poll the player base for. Thinking about it now, I _feel_ like the third group would be bigger than the second group, but it's just a feeling.

However, I don't think Snake is pushing for reduced queue times. I think he's trying to explain the tangible goal of what people want is easily achievable through changing one's secondary role. Why choose fill to hopefully get one of those three other roles you want when you could just change your secondary to one of those three roles that you want the most, and once you get tired of that, change to one of the others? Fill might decrease queue times a bit, but the effect isn't that obvious, and the discomfort from getting a role that one doesn't want is probably greater than the discomfort from waiting X amount of time longer.

I hope this makes sense, since I was doing the thinking as I wrote the post rather than having the thought in mind at the beginning.
